text: Acknowledgements
label: BODY

text: The research for this report was conducted by Roberta Rocca in June and July 2021 as part
label: BODY

text: of the OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data’s Data Fellows Programme. The research was
label: BODY

text: supervised by Leonardo Milano, team lead for predictive analytics at the Centre and Stuart
label: BODY

text: Campo, the lead for the Data Fellows Programme. The findings and recommendations draw
label: BODY

text: primarily on interviews with key informants from ACAPS, ICRC, IDMC, IFRC, the Millennium
label: BODY

text: Institute, OCHA, REACH, the University of Bergen, and WFP. The author gratefully
label: BODY

text: acknowledges the inputs and feedback from everyone involved in this research. The
label: BODY

text: research findings are presented in a descriptive manner based on the author’s analysis.
label: BODY

text: Given the limited duration of the research and relatively small number of key informants, the
label: BODY

text: findings should not be considered to be representative of the entire humanitarian sector.
label: BODY

text: Executive Summary
label: HH1

text: The Global Humanitarian Overview 2021 estimates that 235 million people are in need of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian assistance, with 160 million targeted for assistance in over 30 countries. These
label: BODY

text: estimates are based on needs assessments that take place on a yearly basis to inform
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Needs Overviews and Humanitarian Response Plans in different crisis
label: BODY

text: contexts.1
label: BODY

text: Although efforts are being made to include scenarios and risk projections in humanitarian
label: BODY

text: planning, they largely remain static representations of humanitarian crises at a given
label: BODY

text: moment in time. However, in many humanitarian contexts, the number of people in need of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian assistance can fluctuate over short time scales as a result of sudden shocks
label: BODY

text: (e.g., escalations in armed conflict) or seasonal environmental phenomena (e.g., floods),
label: BODY

text: among other factors. Humanitarians need more robust methods for understanding and
label: BODY

text: modeling these dynamics in order to more effectively address the needs of people affected
label: BODY

text: by crises.
label: BODY

text: Complex systems modeling is a class of mathematical methods that predict the behavior of a
label: BODY

text: system over time based on a set of assumptions on how components of the system interact.
label: BODY

text: These techniques are suited to providing dynamic projections of how a humanitarian crisis
label: BODY

text: will unfold and what effects different potential interventions could have in a given context.
label: BODY

text: Recognizing this potential, the Centre for Humanitarian Data (the Centre) conducted
label: BODY

text: research on opportunities to apply complex systems modeling to humanitarian needs
label: BODY

text: assessment as part of its 2021 Data Fellows Programme. This report summarizes the main
label: BODY

text: findings from the Centre’s research. The first section provides a definition of complex
label: BODY

text: systems and an overview of the main modeling techniques relevant to humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: The second section explains why the use of complex systems modeling would be desirable
label: BODY

text: in the humanitarian sector. The third section outlines feasibility, viability, and desirability
label: BODY

text: criteria that can help assess whether specific problem spaces are suitable to complex
label: BODY

text: systems modeling techniques. The fourth section proposes a general workflow for the
label: BODY

text: development of the most suitable model for humanitarian settings.
label: BODY

text: The research yielded the following key findings:
label: BODY

text: There is strong interest within the humanitarian community in the prospect of using
label: BODY

text: complex systems modeling to improve the ability to understand, predict and respond
label: BODY

text: to the needs of crisis-affected communities.
label: BODY

text: To determine which problems are best suited to being modeled using complex
label: BODY

text: systems techniques, humanitarians should consider the following criteria:
label: BODY

text: Feasibility: clear goals and output; clear target geographic area; existence of
label: BODY

text: previous models and/or literature relevant to the problem space.
label: BODY

text: Viability: data availability; synergy with domain experts and humanitarian
label: BODY

text: actors in the field.
label: BODY

text: Desirability: complexity of the problem space; ability to inform response
label: BODY

text: activities; potential impact.
label: BODY

text: 1 See the Global Humanitarian Overview 2021 for more details: https://hum-insight.info/
label: BODY

text: Out of the techniques considered (network/graph models, agent-based modeling and
label: BODY

text: System Dynamics), System Dynamics is currently the most suitable for a pilot of
label: BODY

text: complex systems modeling in the humanitarian sector. This is due to its potential to
label: BODY

text: support response simulation even in contexts with limited data availability and due to
label: BODY

text: availability of relevant expertise.
label: BODY

text: The main recommendations include:
label: BODY

text: The Centre should coordinate initial pilots to better understand the potential impact of
label: BODY

text: complex systems modeling techniques in the sector. One promising use case relates
label: BODY

text: to infectious diseases modeling. The development of a Cholera Response Simulator
label: BODY

text: (i.e, a model that would make it possible to simulate and evaluate the effectiveness
label: BODY

text: of different possible cholera response strategies) has been identified as a suitable
label: BODY

text: problem space for a pilot and an opportunity to concretely understand the potential
label: BODY

text: impact of these techniques in the sector. More detailed information on this pilot and
label: BODY

text: preliminary data exploration is available in this repository.
label: BODY

text: The Centre should develop partnerships with actors from technical research
label: BODY

text: environments and the development sector, where complex systems modeling is more
label: BODY

text: widely in use.
label: BODY

text: The Centre should create medium-term (6-12 months) research fellowships with
label: BODY

text: academic institutions for students with relevant technical training in systems
label: BODY

text: modeling or sponsor applied doctoral fellowships which would involve sustained
label: BODY

text: collaborations with the Centre on systems modeling projects.
label: BODY

text: The Centre should coordinate events and develop educational resources tailored to
label: BODY

text: humanitarians to increase uptake of these techniques within the sector.
label: BODY

text: To help bridge the technical gaps that constitute the main barrier to the adoption of
label: BODY

text: predictive modeling techniques in the sector, the Centre should leverage its annual
label: BODY

text: Data Fellows Programme to implement projects at the intersection of predictive
label: BODY

text: analytics, data literacy, and data visualization.
label: BODY

text: The Centre should continue its work in closing data gaps and consider how to
label: BODY

text: improve and communicate model accuracy through collaboration between modelers
label: BODY

text: and actors in the field.
label: BODY

text: I. What is a complex system?
label: HH1

text: Many social and natural phenomena can be described as complex systems. The climate is a
label: BODY

text: notable example of a complex system: climate phenomena emerge from the interactions
label: BODY

text: between multiple subsystems, including the atmosphere, oceans and terrestrial ecosystems,
label: BODY

text: (which are themselves complex systems). The nervous system is another notable example:
label: BODY

text: the biological and cognitive functions supported by the system cannot be explained in terms
label: BODY

text: of the ‘sum’ of the activities of single neurons. The behavioral dynamics of both human and
label: BODY

text: non-human social groups can also often be described as complex systems.
label: BODY

text: Complex systems are systems whose global behavior is emergent, non-linear and adaptive:
label: BODY

text: Emergent: It cannot be explained from the behavior of individual components but is
label: BODY

text: said to emerge from the interactions between individual components.
label: BODY

text: Non-linear: Due to the ways in which interactions between the multiple components
label: BODY

text: of the system accumulate, small changes in the behavior of individual components
label: BODY

text: may result in disproportionate effects on the global state of the system.
label: BODY

text: Adaptive: Individual components of the system can change their behavior to adapt to
label: BODY

text: changes in the behavior of other components.
label: BODY

text: Given these properties of emergence, non-linearity and adaptiveness, the behavior of
label: BODY

text: complex systems can only be predicted through techniques that explicitly factor in the
label: BODY

text: dynamic interconnectedness between system components.
label: BODY

text: II. Why use complex systems modeling in the humanitarian
label: HH1

text: sector?
label: HH1

text: Many humanitarian crises can be considered complex systems. Crises often come about as
label: BODY

text: a result of interactions between multiple, mutually reinforcing political, social, and
label: BODY

text: environmental factors, whose effects accumulate over time in non-linear ways. This makes
label: BODY

text: these crises prone to sudden escalations and often resistant to humanitarian intervention.
label: BODY

text: In slow-onset and protracted crises, the effects of the interaction between multiple crisis
label: BODY

text: drivers accumulate non-linearly over long time scales. This is the case, for example, for
label: BODY

text: protracted food insecurity crises, where environmental, social, economic, and geopolitical
label: BODY

text: factors reinforce each other in ways which make interventions targeting single crisis drivers
label: BODY

text: often ineffective. Other crises are punctuated by sudden-onset seasonal shocks, such as
label: BODY

text: floods or typhoons, whose effects propagate to the whole system over very short time
label: BODY

text: scales.
label: BODY

text: To intervene in humanitarian contexts where needs can change dramatically over time,
label: BODY

text: current needs assessment techniques need to be complemented by modeling techniques
label: BODY

text: which factor in these complex systems characteristics. Complex systems modeling can
label: BODY

text: support more effective and data-driven humanitarian response. Modeling techniques that
label: BODY

text: factor in complexity help better predict how and why needs may change over the timeline of
label: BODY

text: a crisis. They also support the development of tools that enable humanitarians to run more
label: BODY

text: dynamic projections of possible scenarios, which can help identify leverage points for
label: BODY

text: interventions to maximise the impact of humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: Complex systems modeling can also help humanitarians understand the likely evolution of
label: BODY

text: the situation at different time scales, enabling responders and policy makers to better
label: BODY

text: understand the short and long-term impacts of planned response activities. In this way, it can
label: BODY

text: provide insights on how to better coordinate humanitarian and development activities in
label: BODY

text: order to address needs while also fostering the coping capacity of affected populations.
label: BODY

text: These models could also help humanitarians understand the unintended consequences that
label: BODY

text: immediate actions could have in the long run.
label: BODY

text: The potential applications of complex systems modeling in humanitarian action have pushed
label: BODY

text: both practitioners and researchers to advocate for its introduction in the sector. Support has
label: BODY

text: also been expressed by the technical experts and humanitarian actors interviewed as a part
label: BODY

text: of this research. In addition, the high level of participation in the Complex Systems Modeling
label: BODY

text: webinar organized by the Centre in June 2021 suggests a more general interest from within
label: BODY

text: the humanitarian and academic communities in partnering to explore the possibilities offered
label: BODY

text: by these new techniques for humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: III. When is complex systems modeling feasible, viable and
label: HH1

text: desirable in humanitarian settings?
label: HH1

text: Not all humanitarian issues are well suited to complex systems modeling. Some may be too
label: BODY

text: vaguely defined to be modeled accurately (e.g., in terms of the target geographical area, the
label: BODY

text: goals, or what factors should be included in the model). Others may require domain
label: BODY

text: knowledge that is not available to the modeler or require data that cannot be collected. While
label: BODY

text: modeling may be feasible in terms of clarity of target and data availability, responding to the
label: BODY

text: model outputs may remain a challenge due to factors such as limited humanitarian access in
label: BODY

text: the area or relevant interventions falling beyond the scope of the response.
label: BODY

text: Before embarking on the development of a complex systems model, humanitarians should
label: BODY

text: evaluate whether the problem space meets a number of feasibility, viability, and desirability
label: BODY

text: criteria outlined in Figure 1 and described in more detail below. These criteria are based on a
label: BODY

text: review of modeling literature as well as the interviews conducted with modeling experts and
label: BODY

text: humanitarians as part of this research.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1. Criteria for determining the feasibility, viability and desirability of complex
label: HH1

text: systems modeling in humanitarian settings
label: BODY

text: Feasibility
label: BODY

text: Viability
label: BODY

text: Desirability
label: BODY

text: Clear goals and output
label: BODY

text: Data availability
label: BODY

text: Complexity of the problem
label: BODY

text: space
label: BODY

text: Clear target geographic
label: BODY

text: area
label: BODY

text: Synergy with domain
label: BODY

text: experts and humanitarian
label: BODY

text: actors in the field
label: BODY

text: Ability to inform response
label: BODY

text: activities
label: BODY

text: Existence of previous
label: BODY

text: models and/or literature
label: BODY

text: Potential impact
label: BODY

text: Feasibility criteria
label: HH1

text: The following criteria help determine whether it is feasible to model a specific problem space
label: BODY

text: using complex systems methods:
label: BODY

text: Clear goals and outputs: The possibility to develop a model depends on clearly
label: BODY

text: specified goals and outputs. This translates into defining: a) what the applications of
label: BODY

text: the model should be; b) what exactly the model should predict/monitor dynamically;
label: BODY

text: c) how confident one is that this/these variable(s) adequately reflect the type of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian need one wants to address through intervention. Model development
label: BODY

text: will be a challenge if any of these points is underspecified.
label: BODY

text: Clear target geographic area: Successful model development requires the
label: BODY

text: identification of a specific target geographical area (at least for initial iterations of
label: BODY

text: model development). This criterion is specific to applications of complex systems
label: BODY

text: modeling to humanitarian crises, where drivers may be highly specific from crisis to
label: BODY

text: crisis, and domain knowledge on the context will be necessary to develop a plausible
label: BODY

text: model of the crisis.
label: BODY

text: Existence of previous models and/or literature: The existence of literature on
label: BODY

text: systems modeling for the problem space of interest supports (but is not essential to)
label: BODY

text: the feasibility of modeling. Existing work can provide a robust starting point for model
label: BODY

text: development.
label: BODY

text: Viability criteria
label: HH1

text: The following criteria help determine whether model development is viable within the
label: BODY

text: constraints posed by the specific target context(s):
label: BODY

text: Data availability: A core aspect to consider is whether sufficient data are available
label: BODY

text: to support validation and estimation of a model. Data availability (especially historical
label: BODY

text: data) is often a challenge in countries with humanitarian operations. The lack of data
label: BODY

text: can jeopardize the possibility to build reliable predictive tools2’3. Nevertheless,
label: BODY

text: developing the conceptual component of a model may bring value by fostering trust
label: BODY

text: and synergy between stakeholders, even when quantitative model estimation is not
label: BODY

text: possible. Imperfect proxies or imputed data may also be sufficient in contexts when
label: BODY

text: the focus is not on maximizing the accuracy of pointwise prediction of a certain
label: BODY

text: variable at each time point (e.g., daily numbers of cases in an epidemic), but on
label: BODY

text: projecting holistic scenarios and trends (e.g., when and whether the number of cases
label: BODY

text: is expected to rise significantly).
label: BODY

text: Synergy with domain experts and actors in the field: Receiving an explicit
label: BODY

text: endorsement and establishing strong partnerships with domain experts and actors in
label: BODY

text: the field is another key condition for model development to be viable. Although this is
label: BODY

text: the case for many predictive modeling efforts, it is especially important for complex
label: BODY

text: systems modeling. In order to identify direct and indirect drivers of humanitarian
label: BODY

text: needs, formulate hypotheses on how these drivers interact, and best tailor the model
label: BODY

text: to its intended applications, modelers need to rely on knowledge provided by domain
label: BODY

text: experts, decision makers and actors close to operations.
label: BODY

text: Desirability criteria
label: HH1

text: The following criteria help assess whether it is desirable to model a specific problem space
label: BODY

text: through complex systems modeling techniques:
label: BODY

text: Complexity of the problem space: It is essential to consider whether the target
label: BODY

text: problem space displays complex systems characteristics, which can only be captured
label: BODY

text: through dynamic and causal modeling strategies, or whether traditional non-dynamic
label: BODY

text: and non-causal predictive models may yield comparable insights. Preliminary data
label: BODY

text: analyses may help clarify this point. This is a general criterion that applies to complex
label: BODY

text: systems modeling beyond humanitarian settings.
label: BODY

text: Ability to inform response activities: Complex systems models can be used to
label: BODY

text: simply test hypotheses on the structure of causal drivers of a crisis, but their impact
label: BODY

text: on humanitarian response may be significantly larger if they can directly provide
label: BODY

text: decision makers with a tool to test and evaluate the potential consequences of
label: BODY

text: different types of response activities. Considering whether a problem space affords
label: BODY

text: 3 See Centre for Humanitarian Data: State of Open Humanitarian Data 2021, p. 21. Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://centre.humdata.org/the-state-of-open-humanitarian-data-2021/
label: BODY

text: 2 See Bodanac, Nicholas, Predictive Analytics for Anticipatory Action: Challenges and Opportunities, p. 12. Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://data.humdata.org/dataset/2048a947-5714-4220-905b-e662cbcd14c8/resource/89546fb6-b130-4189-9da9-c962053e729
label: BODY

text: f/download/pa_2020_fellow_report_final.pdf.
label: BODY

text: similar applications (and assessing whether decision makers in the target context are
label: BODY

text: open to deploying such a tool) is key to understanding whether the practical benefits
label: BODY

text: justify the time and resources required to develop and validate a complex systems
label: BODY

text: model.
label: BODY

text: Potential impact: It is important to consider whether the trade-off between resources
label: BODY

text: required to develop a model and its overall impact on the context of focus is
label: BODY

text: sustainable. Relatedly, it may be worth considering how likely it is that the model
label: BODY

text: could be re-used for and adapted to other geographical areas, which could support
label: BODY

text: impact beyond the initial context of focus.
label: BODY

text: IV. How is a complex systems model developed?
label: HH1

text: There are a number of modeling techniques that are designed to understand complex
label: BODY

text: systems (see Figure 2 below for more detail). The goals and constraints of the specific
label: BODY

text: problem of interest determine which modeling technique is most appropriate in a given
label: BODY

text: context.
label: BODY

text: The Centre’s research determined that System Dynamics is likely to be the most suitable
label: BODY

text: technique for a pilot of complex systems modeling in the humanitarian sector due to the
label: BODY

text: potential of this technique to support response simulation even in contexts with limited data
label: BODY

text: availability.4 Our research also highlighted how humanitarian and development partners are
label: BODY

text: already exploring the use of System Dynamics modeling (see Figure 3 for more concrete
label: BODY

text: examples).
label: BODY

text: Figure 2. Selected methods for complex systems modeling
label: HH1

text: Complex systems modeling refers to any method that can be used to represent a system of
label: BODY

text: interacting components and predict its behavior given a description of its components and a set of
label: BODY

text: assumptions on the rules that define how the components behave. The following methods are
label: BODY

text: among those most commonly used to model complex systems and with the highest potential
label: BODY

text: relevance for use in the humanitarian sector.
label: BODY

text: Network/graph models: Components of the systems are represented as nodes in a network, and
label: HH1

text: their relations (i.e., whether and how each node interacts with each other) are defined by edges
label: BODY

text: connecting each node (which may include loops, i.e., edges that connect nodes with themselves).
label: BODY

text: Complex networks are a specific class of networks which display special topological features.
label: BODY

text: Small-world networks, for example, are networks where nodes tend to be grouped in tight clusters,
label: BODY

text: but a few long-range connections between nodes make clusters communicate with each other. This
label: BODY

text: is an example of a class of complex networks that is often found in real-world phenomena. In
label: BODY

text: human social networks, for example, small-world properties motivate hypotheses postulating that
label: BODY

text: all people are on average a few social connections away from each other (e.g., the six degrees of
label: BODY

text: separation hypothesis). In addition to the complexity of the network structure itself, these models
label: BODY

text: are also able to capture the evolution of dynamic processes in connected complex networks (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: an epidemic spreading in a society).
label: BODY

text: Agent-based modeling: Agent-based models are computational models that make it possible to
label: HH1

text: simulate the behavior of a system based on a description of (i) the type of agents the system
label: BODY

text: consists of and (ii) the rules on how these agents behave and interact. Agent-based models are a
label: BODY

text: microscale modeling technique: the level of description is that of the individual agents, and the
label: BODY

text: macroscale behavior of the system emerges (over the course of a computer simulation) as a
label: BODY

text: function of the cumulative effects of agents’ behaviors and their interactions over time. Agent-based
label: BODY

text: models are often used to predict the dynamics of epidemic diseases as a function of assumptions
label: BODY

text: on how individuals behave (e.g., the average number and duration of social contacts) and on
label: BODY

text: epidemiological parameters (e.g., incubation time, recovery rate). Beyond epidemiology,
label: BODY

text: agent-based modeling is widely used in a number of other fields (e.g., biology, computational social
label: BODY

text: science, and economics). Agent-based models can be validated against real data to understand
label: BODY

text: 4 Note, however, that this is not a general recommendation for all humanitarian applications. If sufficient data are available and
label: BODY

text: the problem space affords it, other techniques such as agent-based models or network approaches may yield higher predictive
label: BODY

text: accuracy, and be more generalizable across problem spaces.
label: BODY

text: which set of assumptions best explains the emergence of behaviors observed in real life, or used to
label: BODY

text: compare outcomes resulting from alternative sets of assumptions.
label: BODY

text: System Dynamics: System Dynamics is a technique initially developed for business and industrial
label: HH1

text: applications where systems are represented at the macroscale in terms of stocks (system-level
label: BODY

text: variables), flows (relations between stocks), feedback loops, and time delays. Development of a
label: BODY

text: System Dynamics model involves first formulating hypotheses on which variables are relevant to
label: BODY

text: defining the behavior of the system, and how they interact (i.e., formulating a causal loop diagram
label: BODY

text: and a stock and flow diagram). Equations that quantify the flows are then defined in order to run
label: BODY

text: dynamic simulations of how the system will evolve given a description of its initial state. These
label: BODY

text: simulations can be used to clarify how a variety of mutually interacting factors give rise to specific
label: BODY

text: dynamics in a system, and which component of the system someone could intervene on, in order to
label: BODY

text: change the behavior of the system in the desired direction.
label: BODY

text: As described in Figure 2, a System Dynamics model is a way of representing a problem in
label: BODY

text: terms of a graph of variables (“stocks”), relations between variables (“flows”), time delays
label: BODY

text: (the time scale at which these relations take place), and feedback loops. System Dynamics
label: BODY

text: models allow users not only to visualize the complex causal factors that are hypothesized to
label: BODY

text: define the behavior of a system, but also to simulate--given these causal assumptions--how
label: BODY

text: the system may evolve over time, and how external interventions on its components may
label: BODY

text: change the way it evolves. This makes System Dynamics especially suitable to use cases
label: BODY

text: where the aim is to simulate impacts and consequences of a humanitarian response plan
label: BODY

text: and related interventions.
label: BODY

text: Developing a System Dynamics model in the humanitarian sector requires various types of
label: BODY

text: expertise. Domain experts and actors directly involved in response operations in the
label: BODY

text: geographical area of interest are needed to identify relevant variables and formulate
label: BODY

text: hypotheses on how different factors influence each other. Technical experts should be in
label: BODY

text: charge of developing, validating and estimating the model. Coordination actors are needed
label: BODY

text: to develop and maintain synergies between parties involved, and to make sure that modeling
label: BODY

text: efforts are tailored to the needs of the end users.
label: BODY

text: There are four key steps5 in developing a System Dynamics model: 1) problem identification
label: BODY

text: and system conceptualization; 2) model formulation and analysis; 3) model validation; and 4)
label: BODY

text: policy analysis and implementation. These steps are explained in more detail below.
label: BODY

text: Step 1: Problem identification and system conceptualization
label: HH1

text: The problem should be narrowed down to a few concrete goals and outputs. Stakeholders
label: BODY

text: should define which variables the model should predict, and what these predictions will be
label: BODY

text: concretely used for. For example, if the target problem is modeling the unfolding of an
label: BODY

text: epidemic, interviews with stakeholders and experts should be conducted to define whether
label: BODY

text: the model should simply help to monitor the number of cases (e.g., to increase
label: BODY

text: preparedness of the healthcare system) or rather understand how to intervene in order to
label: BODY

text: minimize the number of deaths.
label: BODY

text: 5 These steps are based on the Centre’s findings and existing literature on System Dynamics modeling process (See for
label: BODY

text: instance ‘Aguiar, A. The role of systematic reviews in the System Dynamics modelling process. Syst Res Behav Sci. 2020; 37:
label: BODY

text: If the model should allow simulation of the effect of a response plan, interviews with
label: BODY

text: stakeholders should be conducted to identify a list of specific types of responses the model
label: BODY

text: should be able to evaluate. Expanding on the example above, if the model is intended to
label: BODY

text: help us understand how to minimize deaths due to cholera, interventions such as the
label: BODY

text: distribution of rehydration kits, oral cholera vaccinations, or increased testing capacity may
label: BODY

text: be relevant.
label: BODY

text: Note that this step is optional if the model is not primarily intended to test the effect of a
label: BODY

text: response plan (but, for example, its goal is simply that of making it possible to explore
label: BODY

text: hypotheses on causal drivers of a crisis).
label: BODY

text: Step 2: Model formulation and analysis
label: HH1

text: Factors that may directly or indirectly influence an output variable should be identified
label: BODY

text: through interviews and/or workshops involving domain experts. Decisions should then be
label: BODY

text: made on which factors to include based on relevance and practical considerations. Building
label: BODY

text: on the previous example of an epidemic, even though conflict events may influence the
label: BODY

text: number of deaths from a disease, modelers may decide not to include this variable if such
label: BODY

text: events are sparse or not relevant to response plans in the target context.
label: BODY

text: Hypotheses on how different factors may influence each other (what causes what, and at
label: BODY

text: which delay) should be developed. This step culminates in the formulation of a map or
label: BODY

text: causal loop diagram of the causal structure of the problem. Literature review and input from
label: BODY

text: domain experts and other stakeholders (in the form of bilateral interviews and workshops)
label: BODY

text: are the key instruments to achieving this.
label: BODY

text: Technical actors should review available data sources to identify proxies for the qualitative
label: BODY

text: variables of interest. If no proxy is available, data may be imputed.
label: BODY

text: Step 3: Model validation
label: HH1

text: The resulting causal loop diagram and the description of how relevant variables will be
label: BODY

text: operationalized quantitatively (i.e., which proxy will be used for each variable, and from
label: BODY

text: which datasets this information will be extracted) should be validated by a panel of
label: BODY

text: independent experts. This step may lead to changes in the model. Whenever possible, this
label: BODY

text: step should follow the guidelines of the Centre’s Peer Review Framework for Predictive
label: BODY

text: Analytics in Humanitarian Response.6
label: BODY

text: The model should then be validated against available data. If performance is not satisfactory,
label: BODY

text: the model may be revised. Ideally, an independent dataset should be kept aside for the final
label: BODY

text: validation of the model.
label: BODY

text: Step 4: Policy analysis and implementation
label: HH1

text: If the model is intended to be deployed as a predictive tool or a scenario exploration tool,
label: BODY

text: user-friendly interfaces can be developed to make deployment easier and results more
label: BODY

text: intuitive.
label: BODY

text: 6 Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://data.humdata.org/dataset/2048a947-5714-4220-905b-e662cbcd14c8/resource/76e488d9-b69d-41bd-927c-116d633bac
label: BODY

text: 7b/download/peer-review-framework-2020.pdf
label: BODY

text: End users should be briefed on what use cases the model supports, and on the uncertainties
label: BODY

text: and risks involved in its deployment. The level of detail and contents of these briefings will
label: BODY

text: depend on whether end users will deploy the model with or without mediation from technical
label: BODY

text: staff.
label: BODY

text: Finally, the model should be used to provide end users with insights according to the use
label: BODY

text: case defined in step 1 (problem identification and system conceptualization), allowing them
label: BODY

text: to test the impact of policies and experiment with different scenarios.
label: BODY

text: Figure 3. Examples of System Dynamics models
label: HH1

text: A few System Dynamics models have already been developed in the humanitarian and
label: BODY

text: development sectors. A notable example is the model developed by the Internal
label: BODY

text: Displacement Monitoring Centre at the Norwegian Refugee Council to simulate how
label: BODY

text: displacement in the Horn of Africa is affected by a number of climate and human-induced
label: BODY

text: factors7.
label: BODY

text: While models and applications in the humanitarian sector are still sparse, System
label: BODY

text: Dynamics is more widely used in the development sector. The Millennium Institute has
label: BODY

text: supported the development of a number of models which make it possible to perform
label: BODY

text: dynamic analyses and policy simulations concerning the achievement of the Sustainable
label: BODY

text: Development Goals8.
label: BODY

text: Other examples relevant to the humanitarian sector are models such as World3 and
label: BODY

text: Threshold21, which are inspired by Donella Meadows’ seminal work on systems thinking.
label: BODY

text: These models project scenarios on the dynamics of natural resource availability, climate,
label: BODY

text: and socio-economic parameters over long time spans. These two models and related
label: BODY

text: simulation interfaces are available online9 .
label: BODY

text: 9 See Insight Maker, The World3 model. Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://insightmaker.com/insight/1954/The-World3-Model-Classic-World-Simulation
label: BODY

text: 8 See The Millenium Institute, The Integrated Sustainable Development Goals (iSDG). Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://www.millennium-institute.org/isdg
label: BODY

text: 7 See Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre: Assessing Drought Displacement Risk for Kenyan and Ethiopian pastoralists,
label: BODY

text: Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://www.internal-displacement.org/publications/assessing-drought-displacement-risk-for-kenyan-ethiopian-and-somali-pasto
label: BODY

text: ralists
label: BODY

text: V. What’s next for complex systems modeling?
label: HH1

text: Complex systems modeling is a potentially powerful technique to help improve the
label: BODY

text: effectiveness of humanitarian response. To realize this potential, humanitarians must
label: BODY

text: address a number of challenges including: identifying suitable target problems; effectively
label: BODY

text: coordinating the multiple actors involved; finding relevant data; and bridging the technical
label: BODY

text: gaps that may cause resistance towards adopting these techniques in the context of
label: BODY

text: decision making.
label: BODY

text: To better understand the potential impact of complex systems modeling techniques in
label: HH1

text: the sector, the Centre should coordinate initial pilots for different types of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian crises. Due to their highly dynamic nature and their impact on affected
label: BODY

text: communities, epidemic disease modeling is a good use case for an initial pilot. More
label: BODY

text: specifically, in line with the feasibility, viability and desirable criteria identified in this report,
label: BODY

text: the development of a Cholera Response Simulator10 could be a suitable opportunity to
label: BODY

text: concretely understand the potential impact of these techniques in the sector. The Centre
label: BODY

text: should further explore this opportunity according to the proposed roadmap for development.
label: BODY

text: To advance this work, the Centre should develop partnerships with actors from
label: HH1

text: technical research environments and the development sector, where complex
label: BODY

text: systems modeling is more widely in use. Institutions such as the Millennium Institute and
label: BODY

text: consortia such as the Complex Systems Society11 are examples of research partners that
label: BODY

text: could help humanitarians to better understand the possibilities offered by complex systems
label: BODY

text: modeling.
label: BODY

text: The impact of initial pilots and of potential subsequent work on complex system modeling
label: BODY

text: conducted at the Centre would benefit from additional in-house expertise and longer-term
label: BODY

text: collaborations with technical experts. The Centre should create medium-term (6-12
label: BODY

text: months) research fellowships with academic institutions for students with relevant
label: BODY

text: technical training in systems modeling or sponsor applied doctoral fellowships which
label: BODY

text: would involve sustained collaborations with the Centre on systems modeling
label: BODY

text: projects.
label: BODY

text: Although complex systems modeling is gaining awareness in the sector, adoption of these
label: BODY

text: techniques in humanitarian contexts is still relatively limited. This is due to the level of
label: BODY

text: technical expertise required to understand how these methods work and how they can
label: BODY

text: inform humanitarian decision making. To support uptake of these techniques within the
label: BODY

text: sector (and ideally, in the longer term, their implementation as part of the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: planning cycles or the anticipatory action plans), the Centre should coordinate events and
label: BODY

text: develop educational resources tailored to humanitarians.
label: BODY

text: The Centre should leverage its annual Data Fellows Programme to implement projects
label: HH1

text: at the intersection of predictive analytics, data literacy, and data visualization. Projects
label: BODY

text: 11 The Complex Systems Society is already committed to exploring applications of systems modeling in sectors adjacent to the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector. See: https://www.cnn.group.cam.ac.uk/news/CCS2021-Complex-Systems-for-the-most-vulnerable.
label: BODY

text: 10 As part of this research, we developed a roadmap for the development of a Cholera Response Simulator based on System
label: BODY

text: Dynamics techniques. We assessed the main data requirements and methodological challenges. This work has been done in
label: BODY

text: collaboration with a student from the University of Bergen, Norway. More information is available in the GitHub repository linked
label: BODY

text: above.
label: BODY

text: may be centered on developing educational resources that help humanitarians navigate
label: BODY

text: existing methods and understanding how these methods map onto possible problem spaces
label: BODY

text: and applications. In practice, this could be done by developing a predictive modeling
label: BODY

text: cheat-sheet illustrated by examples, or a set of notebooks (e.g., as Jupyter books, or
label: BODY

text: Observable notebooks) which introduces the reader to different techniques through toy
label: BODY

text: models. The Centre could also supplement its catalogue of predictive models12 with practical
label: BODY

text: demonstrations of the main models.
label: BODY

text: Finally, limited data availability and poor data quality is one of the main barriers to the
label: BODY

text: development of complex systems models. The Centre should continue its work on
label: BODY

text: closing data gaps and consider how to improve and communicate model accuracy
label: BODY

text: through collaboration between modelers and actors in the field.
label: BODY
